psalm.text:
[[1_S 2,1]]My heart exults in the LORD, 
my horn is exalted in my God. 
I have swallowed up my enemies; 
I rejoice in my victory.

[[1_S 2,4]]The bows of the mighty are broken, 
while the tottering gird on strength.
[[1_S 2,5]]The well-fed hire themselves out for bread, 
while the hungry batten on spoil. 
The barren wife bears seven sons, 
while the mother of many languishes.

[[1_S 2,6]]The LORD puts to death and gives life; 
He casts down to the nether world; 
He raises up again.
[[1_S 2,7]]The LORD makes poor and makes rich, 
He humbles, he also exalts.

[[1_S 2,8a]]He raises the needy from the dust;
[[1_S 2,8b]]from the dung heap he lifts up the poor,
[[1_S 2,8c]]to seat them with nobles
[[1_S 2,8d]]and make a glorious throne their heritage.
psalm.title: 1st book of Samuel

gospel.text:
[[Mc 1,21b]]Jesus came to Capernaum with his followers, and on the sabbath he entered the synagogue and taught.
[[Mc 1,22]]The people were astonished at his teaching, for he taught them as one having authority and not as the scribes.
[[Mc 1,23]]In their synagogue was a man with an unclean spirit;
[[Mc 1,24]]he cried out, "What have you to do with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are--the Holy One of God!"
[[Mc 1,25]]Jesus rebuked him and said, "Quiet! Come out of him!"
[[Mc 1,26]]The unclean spirit convulsed him and with a loud cry came out of him.
[[Mc 1,27]]All were amazed and asked one another, "What is this? A new teaching with authority. He commands even the unclean spirits and they obey him."
[[Mc 1,28]]His fame spread everywhere throughout the whole region of Galilee.
gospel.title: Holy Gospel of Jesus Christ according to Saint Mark

first_reading.text:
[[1_S 1,9]]Hannah rose after a meal at Shiloh, and presented herself before the LORD; at the time, Eli the priest was sitting on a chair near the doorpost of the LORD's temple.
[[1_S 1,10]]In her bitterness she prayed to the LORD, weeping copiously,
[[1_S 1,11]]and she made a vow, promising: "O LORD of hosts, if you look with pity on the misery of your handmaid, if you remember me and do not forget me, if you give your handmaid a male child, I will give him to the LORD for as long as he lives; neither wine nor liquor shall he drink, and no razor shall ever touch his head."
[[1_S 1,12]]As she remained long at prayer before the LORD, Eli watched her mouth,
[[1_S 1,13]]for Hannah was praying silently; though her lips were moving, her voice could not be heard. Eli, thinking her drunk,
[[1_S 1,14]]said to her, "How long will you make a drunken show of yourself? Sober up from your wine!"
[[1_S 1,15]]"It isn't that, my lord," Hannah answered. "I am an unhappy woman. I have had neither wine nor liquor; I was only pouring out my troubles to the LORD.
[[1_S 1,16]]Do not think your handmaid a ne'er-do-well; my prayer has been prompted by my deep sorrow and misery."
[[1_S 1,17]]Eli said, "Go in peace, and may the God of Israel grant you what you have asked of him."
[[1_S 1,18]]She replied, "Think kindly of your maidservant," and left. She went to her quarters, ate and drank with her husband, and no longer appeared downcast.
[[1_S 1,19]]Early the next morning they worshiped before the LORD, and then returned to their home in Ramah. When Elkanah had relations with his wife Hannah, the LORD remembered her.
[[1_S 1,20]]She conceived, and at the end of her term bore a son whom she called Samuel, since she had asked the LORD for him.
first_reading.title: 1st book of Samuel
